BoRGTom Overview

From Robert:

The 'Semantic Web Initiative' proclaimed by the W3C is also dealing with storing web information not as text but also using RDF for simplified semantic networks. The Bond Research Group for Topic Maps (BoRGToM) is conducting R&D with a competing technology, Topic Maps (TM), which has gained industrial dynamics in Europe.

Our research ranges from analyzing business cases for TM based applications and services up to more theoretical research in semantic models for TMs. The group of 6 full time staff members and a varying number of students is also actively involved in the international standardisation for languages to constrain and query TMs.

Recent achievements have been a set of software packages targeted for developing Topic Map applications. Other packages implement an abstract engine for content syndication using XML (and other formats) to carry content, and Topic Maps for content meta data. TM visualisation methods are currently evaluated.

BoRGTom News

From Robert:

Hi,

Some news to keep you all posted:

- As mentioned previously, I have invited Gernot Salzer from

Austria to have a look what we are doing in the semantics

area.

- Currently the industry consortium working on a "standard

application model" SAM has released a draft. I have provided

them with some feedback on this document. If you are interested

http://www.y12.doe.gov/sgml/sc34/document/0299.htm

The idea is that a query/constraint language will be used based

on this model. Not exactly an easy task, I think. A standalone

semantics might be easier to develop a query language.

Only then a mapping into this model makes sense. (Model has been

defined by programmers, argh :-).

- Daniel has submitted his thesis. It is not also rather fat, it

is one of the very best I have seen so far. We already have

factored out some articles, but this needs further work.

- Last week I experimented with this TM->BibTeX converter. It

is a bit flaky and I need a bit more ideas to make it more

robust/flexible.

Still, nothing should stop you to collect your literature using

AsTMa= and then convert it into BibTeX dbs. We had a test run

with Daniel's thesis and it worked, more-or-less.

This would be an interesting student project. Good to outsource.

- This week I followed a suggestion from Lars (Marius Garshol) for

our new site

http://topicmaps.it.bond.edu.au/

He indicated that he would be willing to contribute content

in form of a 'weblog'. Have a look at http://www.blogger.com/

sign up and write your weblog (also known as blog).

This has becomes some sort of fashion but is an easy way

for people to publish their ideas/comments/views in form of

a diary.

I have implemented a blog taglib for our XML application server

and do testing under

http://topicmaps.it.bond.edu.au/index2.mc

Compare the weblog content there with

http://drrho.blogspot.com/

 

- Finding article authors for the site is not easy. Most have other

obligations and publish on their company sites. I will continue

to try.

One has already sent me a fat article about Java development. I

will have to do some programming to make that work.

- As you have noted, I have placed a plug about our research into

the next ICT issue.

- I also added Samrat to the members list. He was missing for some

reasons.

- I plan to do a talk at Griffith and/or SEA Brisbane about Knowledge

Organisation with TMs. Any contacts?

rho
